keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's first ex-president to go to jail, is serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with Libyan money.
Sarkozy was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, not of personally receiving funds.
The case originated from meetings in 2005 between Sarkozy's aides and Libyan officials through intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine.
Sarkozy has appealed his conviction and remains innocent, asserting that the sentence is unjust and politically motivated.
He is held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, in an isolation wing, with limited contact and restricted movement.
He has been granted basic prison amenities including a small desk, toilet, shower, TV, fridge, and family contact rights.
President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin have publicly supported Sarkozy, with Macron acknowledging the emotional impact on the public and Darmanin committing to visit him.
Sarkozy has refused special treatment and will serve his sentence under standard prison conditions, despite being in isolation.
The case is highly controversial and reflects broader tensions between political accountability and political loyalty in post-authoritarian democratic systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's first ex-president to go to jail, begins a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Though he was not convicted of personally receiving funds, he was found guilty of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who arranged secret meetings with Libyan officials via intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. Sarkozy has appealed the conviction and maintains his innocence, claiming the case is politically motivated and that the sentence reflects a desire for revenge. He is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison in an isolation wing, with limited contact and movement. President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin have publicly expressed support, with Darmanin pledging a visit. The case is part of a broader controversy over political accountability and foreign influence in democratic processes, and a final verdict on Sarkozy's appeal is expected in late November 2025.
